transcription.text: Thank you everybody for coming and this year was really interesting. We had so many amazing
submissions and we're really excited. The judges deliberated until maybe 2 a.m. yesterday.
So it was really, really tight this year. One of the criteria is that we're going to discuss
in the panel. This session is a little different from last year. We're going to have a panel
with the judges to discuss the state of UX and design as well as and we'll touch upon
all these points of the criteria. And our judges, I'm really excited to introduce, we
have Benny from CryptoKitties and Dapper Labs. And then we have Alex from Coinbase. Joining
us from product design. And then, we're actually really excited to bring back Arjor. Arjor was
the winner, one of the winners of last year. And so they're coming back as a judge. And
it's really great to see how far everyone has come. And Jamie, the UX design director
is not here today. But we have Julian, who is one of the co-founders of Arjor. Cool.
So we're going to start this panel. Just kind of talking about where are we in the same
UX. I know we've been talking a lot about UX and design. But coming from such product
oriented and you guys have quite a sweep of products. You have Hopper, you have Coinbase
Pro, you guys have a new blockchain now. So, Benny, you start with a little bit of where
you think we are in the design space specifically in 1.3.
Yeah, it's very interesting. Coming from the game space, we have almost more than 50% of
the company is focusing on the game studio side. So designing UX and UI for games is
much more different from DeFi. Fortunately, we spend a lot of time with our top players
of CryptoPities and Cheese Wizards, our new game. And we get to learn a lot about the different
pain points that they have. And the pain points that gamers have or blockchain gamers have
is very different from somebody who wants to make a compound loan or use-point base.
They have a higher expectation of the flow being extremely smooth. And so that's kind
of like, at least from the game side, what we think about a lot.
Yeah. And what are some of the things that maybe you guys can kind of come in? The things
that we're doing right and what things we're doing wrong, maybe Argent, you guys can start
as well. That's a great question. I think we are starting
to do a lot of things right. I think maybe to compliment your first question, I think
this is a very exciting period because the blockchain and Ethereum is still a young technology.
And I think we are gradually reaching outside of small crypto bubble. And I think a lot of
the capability is done through improving the user experience. I think, especially for margin,
it comes from technology. And I think we try to solve problem by the technology first
thing. But I think this is really an exciting time because we get to show this amazing technology
to the outside world while still maintaining its core principle. And I think this is something
that is very important, is to being able to reach to people that may be less tech savvy,
but still maintain or core principle about decentralization.
I mean, you're kind of the design, product design representative here. What are some
of the design opportunities that we've had and what's going on in space?
I echo what you said. Having sat through UX audits, I think we came a really long way
from early big decentralized products that were very much focused on exploring that technology
to building more and more user-friendly, user-focused things. We are as complex, like you guys, as
companies, we start to focus more on basically solving user needs, finding the good company,
creating good mental models. I think we still have some challenges to overcome. We still
sort of, I see projects designing for just the fun of technology. But I think we're going
in a good direction of putting the user first and having the user introduced, like being
able to introduce the user to the crypto.
Yeah, I mean, so going towards that, in your company, you guys have kind of one of the
most well-adoption in products with well-adopted features. So what does design look like in
your process? There's a lot of kind of, as we saw from the UX audits, a lot of teams
that come in and we're like, we don't have a designer, we don't know what to do. So
how did that start from you guys and how does that grow currently in the current state?
Yeah, maybe give a hand start here. I think for us, design start by thinking about the
user. So in everything we do, we first really focus on the user and to give an example when
we started Origin, we're thinking about, you know, how to manage your account or your
keys. And we will try to think what's a user experience that people actually understand,
people outside of our bubble. And we realized that the user of the experience of banks,
for example, we mean it like banks, traditional banks. But the idea that if you lose your credit
card, you use your wallet, you can actually call your bank to give a new one. We kind
of felt like this was a mental model that users would understand. So we tried to replicate
that. First, he's using the technology. That's why we build a smart contract with wallet.
And then adding a layer of UX and design on top of it. So for us, the starting point is
the user trying to solve the problem for a user. Then we use the technology and then
we use shiny button, good design, you know, flows and stuff like that. I think the starting
point is really to start from the user. One, traditionally, I think in an ecosystem where
people are very tech savvy, we tend to start from the technology. We build a cool technology
and then we think, okay, you know, all with the user, we use my technology. I think the
paradigm needs to be shaped. You should be, okay, I solved the problem for a user and
then find the right technology to solve that. Yeah, you're kind of going touching upon the
next question here about users and although we are having this really interesting conversation
around how do you find your users and how do you define who your user group is? So, you
know, as we know, Coinbase has a portfolio of different products. And I both Castoldio
and Non-Castoldio. And I think what we're doing really well is kind of understanding
that not about not an entire group of our users is the same. So, we kind of funnel them
into different, into different places. And with having that in mind, we actually do talk
to our users very early as well. We, I mean, we just had this discussion of like, it is
a lot of teams say that it is very difficult to find a user group without breaking their
privacy. And I claim the opposite. It's just you basically need to hassle a little bit
and reach out to your community, reach out, use different platforms, ask people to come
to your office or just set up Hangouts and just talk to your user, understand what their
pain points are, understand what they kind of expect. You will learn that maybe your
initial assumptions are completely in a different place than what your users really think. And
I think in our case, it's one of the things that builds the biggest advantage in how we
think about our products.
Then, yeah, I'm excited to hear your answer because I've talked to your design team and
you guys have just started unraveling user research and reaching out with cheese wizards.
What does that look like for you guys?
So cheese wizards stand from us being in a room and thinking about what is the next
weirdest thing we could build, both from a technical standpoint or building a battle
royal blockchain game and the sense of mixing cheese with wizards. So we have that kind
of luxury of thinking creatively of what will take a loss and how can we kind of emanate
that as a project.
Then we kind of go through the step of building really fast prototypes that are off-chain
and we like to test it. We've done probably by now more than 10 play tests of cheese wizards
internally and each iteration we kind of improve the way it looks, the way the flow goes.
Recently, about three weeks ago, we had the last final play test for cheese wizards on
the Ring B network. It was pretty much, it had most of the features that we have set
the launch for next week.
What we did was I built a battle cage inside of the office and curated duels between different
people in the company. Not only that, we had the user research team that was sitting there
and kind of asking questions and mapping out the user journey and their emotions through
the entire process of going through the flow.
From that, we also sent a daily service to capture all the information from the team
members. We usually start with internal, then we invite a core group of maybe a small
sample size of external players to come and play and we do the same thing where we measure
every day and see where we can improve and then that gets funneled to engineering and
design.
Then now we're at this point where we have an open beta this entire week. We welcome
the entire space here at DevCon and our community to play the game. We have on the website any
bugs or issues, feel free to fill out the form. That's how we usually capture a lot of the
information, funnel it up to design and engineering and then build up those features inside the
game.
I want to pull from that user research component of it. That's been a big narrative. This year
at DevCon last year, it was kind of like massive option, massive option. Before that, it was
like how do we understand and get to know our users better. Pulling from that, we were
just talking about market research versus design research. The team from Cellos said
it really well which is with market research, you might get 100 people and get 10 insights.
With design research, you get 10 people and get 100 insights. You're going super deep
and taking that time to ask them not just questions about your product but questions
around how do you go about your flow, your goal. How do you get a person to finish that
goal?
Maybe it's like going to the bank, okay, what happens if you lost your money? Where do you
go? It doesn't have to be directly correlated to your product because you're not trying
to tell them this is the product that's going to solve your needs if you don't know what
those needs are yet.
Let's go back to use a usability and what I call the responsibility of the creator. You
guys have one of the biggest products. You literally broke Ethereum. What do you guys
find that for your users, what do you guys try to do to protect them or give them kind
of the space? What's different in the way that you're creating product that you think

You want to start?
Go ahead.
So is it in comparison to how other blockchain games build games and the way that they build

Yeah, it's hard because you guys all have so many different products. I would say, I
think generally a lot of people are thinking about how they build the product. When you're
building the product, there's fundamental kind of decisions in that you create while
you're creating the product and that has to do with kind of the underlying needs or needs.
I think for me it's about, of course, you make choice when you design a product and
you make choice on the app of the user. But I think something that's very important is
to inform the user about these choices and making sure you don't ID anything. So I think
users have to make conscious choices and know maybe the compromise they are making.
Some users are fine using a custodial service. Some users may not be. So I think it's important
that actually we educate, not educate, we inform the user about the choice that he's
making and the trade-off that he may get from the choice that he's making. I think this
is something for us that's very important. Also, at Arjun, we believe that there is a

a question of informing the users and helping in making a wise choice because it's easy
to badly inform or to add something and make decision. I think it's actually the UX is
really responsible of that. It's leading the user to inform about the choice that he's making.
Yeah, I want to pull that up a pull from that and I will get to you because there's
some ideas around the abstraction with information to avoid complexity for the user. And so I
know Coinbase has pro, you guys have custodial, non-custodial, you guys have different kinds

I think as long as coming from the crypto community, I would want to say that let's do, I would
want to believe that we should make users think. It's not exactly how the product works. And
I think certain features are in the existing financial system, therefore a reason. So for

So we can, in wallet for example, we allow users to back their security, their secret

I really like that idea that evolution, we've heard evolution. I think we've already

systems centralization. But the adoption that we see there and that bridge, we're almost
there, but we're trying to design for a user that's users that are not quite there yet.
They're not that knowledgeable. I think that's a difficulty of the moment we are in is that
this is some kind of tension because you want to build for the next wave of users coming,
but we still want to be relevant today. And so what people understand today is not what
people will understand in the future. And to give you a good example about that, I have
a good friend that I managed to convince to use Origin and he was really excited to put

Origin. And I said, yes, look at that screen. He says we can send ESG20. He's like, what's
an ESG20? So actually on Coinbase, he converted his guy to Ether. So he could send Ether. And
then on Origin converted the Ether back to die. By the time he had done that, he had
lost like six or seven percent. He was like, your product makes no sense. And I think we're
saying about understanding our users. I think there's also a lot of feedback. And we need

because we do use the research we need our users. But actually listening to the feedback
of the users is the so you learn the most because we make a lot of assumption of what
people understand and what people know. That example for us was like, of course, nobody
